channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Explosions Rock Main Airport in Istanbul
item.media:description: Paramedics at Ataturk airport in Istanbul after two explosions there Tuesday night.
item.description: The Interior Ministry said 10 people were killed and about 20 more injured at Ataturk airport by two blasts that appeared to be from suicide bombings.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Economic Fears Rising, Britain Hopes to Stay in E.U. Market
item.media:description: Boris Johnson left his home in London on Monday.
item.description: Leaders on both sides of the “Brexit” debate signaled that they wanted continued access to the free-trade zone, though the European Union may have other ideas.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER, STEPHEN CASTLE and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: France’s Far Right Sees an Opportunity in ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, the leader of France’s far-right National Front party, at a special session of the European Parliament in Brussels on Tuesday.
item.description: Marine Le Pen, the National Front leader and a presidential candidate, has seized on Britain’s vote to leave the European Union to press the case for a referendum in France.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn, Leader of Britain’s Labour Party, Loses No-Confidence Vote
item.media:description: The Labour Party leader, Jeremy Corbyn, leaving his home in London on Tuesday.
item.description: The decision reflected sharp divisions between the party’s leadership and its grass-roots base after Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: News Analysis: Leaders of ‘Brexit’ Campaign, Having Won, Turn to Managing Expectations
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former London mayor, on Tuesday. One thing has become especially clear about him and other leaders of the successful campaign to vote Britain out of the European Union: They have no plan for what comes next.
item.description: A change in tone may be necessary, analysts say, but it also holds considerable political peril for Boris Johnson and other Conservative Party leaders.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Shakes Up Military Command
item.media:description: Gen. Hassan Firouzabadi in 2010. He was replaced as chief of staff of the Iranian armed forces on Tuesday.
item.description: The longtime chief of staff of the Iranian armed forces was removed, without explanation, in favor of his deputy, a member of the Revolutionary Guards.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Israeli Military Revokes Use of Maximum Force to Foil Captures
item.media:description: Israel Defense Forces tanks near the border with Gaza in 2014. At least 135 Palestinians were said to have been killed that year in an Israeli barrage after a soldier was captured.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The military’s chief of staff has given instructions to revoke the decades-old “Hannibal procedure” and formulate a new policy, a military official said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Florida Jury Finds Former Chilean Officer Liable in ’73 Killing
item.media:description: Víctor Jara, a popular folk singer, songwriter and theater director, was murdered days after the 1973 military coup that brought Gen. Augusto Pinochet to power.
item.media:credit: Fundacion Víctor Jara, via Associated Press
item.description: A jury decided that Pedro Pablo Barrientos, a naturalized American, was behind the killing of a popular folk singer, Víctor Jara, in Chile during the coup that brought Pinochet to power.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Climate Change High on Agenda as Obama and Trudeau Meet for Summit
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada at the White House in March. They will meet again Wednesday at a summit meeting in Ottawa.
item.description: Leaders of the United States, Mexico and Canada will announce a climate partnership, synchronizing their national policies to cut greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN and CORAL DAVENPORT
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Chinese Textbook Calls Women Who Have Premarital Sex ‘Degenerates’
item.media:description: A couple in a park in Beijing, China, this month. Sex education is inconsistent in Chinese schools.
item.description: A teacher in southern China posted photos online from the sex ed textbook, which predicts dire consequences for women who have sex before marriage. The post unleashed a firestorm of comments.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Chongqing Journal: ‘Destined to Disappear’: The Last Generation of China’s ‘Bang-Bang Army’
item.media:description: A porter in Chongqing, in China, in April. The number of porters is estimated to have shrunk from as many as 300,000 in the 1990s to no more than 10,000 in the city today.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The street porters of Chongqing are on the decline as courier vans and bikes cut into business and younger people reject such poorly paid, backbreaking work.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: US First Lady Promotes Learning to Empower Moroccan Girls
item.description: Michelle Obama told Moroccan teenage girls that her parents knew the value of education, her brother set an example "and I thought if he can do it, then I can do it, because I know I am smarter than him!"
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Unicef Says Its Development Goals for Children Are at Risk
item.media:description: Anthony Lake, the executive director of United Nations Children’s Fund, in 2015.
item.description: The United Nations children’s agency projected that by 2030, almost 70 million children will have died from preventable causes.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Jeremy Corbyn, E.U. Reaction and Likelihood of Divorce
item.media:description: Demonstrators who support continued membership in the European Union gathered in Trafalgar Square in London on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Britain’s political leadership has frayed at the top, and European Union leaders are anxiously responding to British voters’ decision to leave the bloc.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Court Orders Apology Over Challenge to Tale of Wartime Heroes
item.media:description: Chinese troops marching in September during the military parade in Beijing for the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II. The parade included a formation in honor of the “Five Heroes of Langya Mountain.”
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Rolex Dela Pena
item.description: A court in Beijing said that a historian, Hong Zhenkuai, had defamed five men said to have fended off Japanese troops during World War II.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: The Interpreter: A Guide to Catching Up on ‘Brexit’ and Reading the Tea Leaves
item.media:description: Near Piccadilly Circus in London on Monday. Over 17 million people voted on Thursday for Britain to disengage from the European Union.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: This list will help you understand what’s going on and why, whether you’re just trying to grasp the basics or have been following all along but seek a deeper understanding.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: E.U. Leaders Divided Over How to Respond to ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Demonstrators in support of the European Union gathered in Trafalgar Square in London on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A two-day summit meeting of European leaders has begun the long and divisive effort to rebuild the cornerstone of Europe’s peace and relative prosperity for more than 60 years.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Order of Business for E.U. in Brussels? Weeds, Then ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain arriving at a summit meeting of European leaders in Brussels on Tuesday.
item.description: As leaders gather for the first time since Britain’s vote, regulatory minutiae will come first, illustrating why so many view the bloc as a meddling bureaucratic machine.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER

item.title: Elaborate Suicide Attack Hits Christian Village in Lebanon
item.description: While bombings have hit Beirut and elsewhere during the Syrian war, such assaults have been rare in the area of Monday’s attack.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: DealBook: ‘Brexit’ Doesn’t Mean Game Over, but It May Be Just the First Domino
item.media:description: Pedestrians walked past the Bank of England on Monday. London stocks extended their losses by early afternoon after Britain voted last week to leave the European Union.
item.description: Yes, Britain’s economy is likely to suffer in the near term, but the most dire effects of the country’s split from the E.U. may be felt on the Continent.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

item.title: Spain’s Vote Deals Setback to Podemos, a Rising Protest Party
item.media:description: Mariano Rajoy, Spain’s caretaker prime minister, during a news conference on Monday. His Popular Party won the most votes in Sunday’s election, halting advances made by the left-wing Podemos party.
item.description: The radical left-wing party fell short of expectations in Sunday’s election as the Popular Party of Mariano Rajoy won the most votes.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: The Interpreter: How Britain Could Exit ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: The afternoon rush in London on Monday. Technically, the “Brexit” referendum result is not legally binding, but the alternatives are tricky for Britain’s leaders.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The country has a few options for how it might remain in the European Union. Each carries significant risks — but, then again, so does leaving.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Seeking to Improve Ties With Russia, Turkey Apologizes for Downing Warplane
item.media:description: Turkey shot down a Russian warplane in November, saying it had violated Turkish airspace.
item.description: The same day Turkey announced a rapprochement with Israel, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan expressed regret about the downing of a Russian warplane last year.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Gay Catholic Groups Want Pope Francis to Do More Than Apologize
item.description: Pope Francis’ comments about the church’s needing to apologize to gays for previous mistreatment must be followed by changes in teachings, the groups said.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Edward Snowden Criticizes ‘Big Brother’ Measure in Russia
item.description: Mr. Snowden, who took refuge in Russia after leaking classified United States data, called a Russian bill an assault on free speech.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: As Migrants Face Abuse, Fear That ‘Brexit’ Has Given License to Xenophobia
item.media:description: One poster, released during the referendum campaign by the far-right U.K. Independence Party, showed a huge line of migrants snaking into the distance and was condemned even by some members of the “Leave” side.
item.description: Amid reports of attacks and graffiti aimed at Britain’s immigrants, human rights advocates and politicians expressed alarm that the vote had unleashed simmering hatred.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Diplomatic Deal With Turkey Upsets Israelis Wary of Conceding Too Much
item.media:description: One of several Israeli assault boats pulled alongside the Turkish passenger ship Mavi Marmara during a 2010 raid by Israeli naval commandos, the episode that set off the diplomatic crisis between the once-close regional allies.
item.media:credit: Kate Geraghty/Sydney Morning Herald, via Getty Images
item.description: Israel will pay $20 million to families of activists killed during an Israeli raid and will allow aid to enter Gaza, but the bodies of two Israeli soldiers will not be returned.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: What Leaders Said Before ‘Brexit,’ and What They Say Now
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, with the Leave campaign’s bus in York, England, last month.
item.description: Political leaders on both sides of the debate are saying distinctly different things now to the promises they made before last week’s referendum.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: U.S. Investigates Whether Airstrikes Killed Taliban Hostages
item.media:description: Afghan security personnel prepared for an operation against Taliban militants in the Aliabad District of Kunduz Province earlier this month.
item.description: Afghan officials agree that the American military conducted drone strikes in a remote area dominated by the Taliban, but give widely divergent accounts of what happened.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Kurdish Rebels Clash With Iran’s Revolutionary Guards
item.description: Kurds and Iranians have been fighting for decades on the Iraq-Iran border, a desolate area that was once the seat of a short-lived Kurdish republic.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Pro-‘Brexit’ City of Sunderland Glad to Poke Establishment in the Eye
item.media:description: Washington, a neighborhood of Sunderland, England, close to a Nissan plant. The city, a former shipbuilding center now plagued by high unemployment, voted overwhelmingly for the “Brexit.”
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Sunderland, England, a former shipbuilding center with high unemployment, voted overwhelmingly for leaving the European Union, though the city benefited from the bloc.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Memo From Bangladesh: To U.S. in ’70s, a Dissenting Diplomat. To Bangladesh, ‘a True Friend.’
item.media:description: Archer K. Blood at the American Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, in 1966. His 1971 “dissent cable” urged condemnation of Pakistan’s assault on Dhaka.
item.description: A cable by Archer K. Blood, the first ever sent through the State Department’s “dissent channel,” called on Washington to condemn its ally Pakistan’s bloody assault on Dhaka.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Chinese Police Detain Activist Who Documents Labor Protests
item.description: Lu Yuyu, whom the authorities have accused of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble,” was taken into custody on June 16 in Dali, his friends said.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Text of Statement by George Osborne, Chancellor of Exchequer, on ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, speaking in Liverpool, England, this month.
item.description: Mr. Osborne, who is in charge of economic policy, appealed for calm before financial markets opened in London.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: ISIS Is Said to Claim Responsibility for Attack at Jordan-Syria Border
item.media:description: The Ruqban refugee camp in Jordan’s northeast border. The Jordanian government responded to a suicide attack last week by sealing its borders with Syria.
item.description: The assault last week killed seven members of the Jordanian security forces, said a news agency that often serves as a conduit for reports about the group.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: What in the World: It’s Dogs vs. Poachers in the Fight to Protect Elephants
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photo by Jagodka/Shutterstock
item.description: Tanzania has trained four Belgian Malinois to check cargo and luggage for smuggled ivory at the main airport and port in Dar es Salaam.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON

item.title: What in the World: Cartoons Keep Order at Japanese Construction Sites
item.media:description: Hello Kitty construction barriers lined a street this month in the Shinjuku district of Tokyo.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Road signs and traffic cones have gone “kawaii,” or cute, all over the country in an effort to entertain passers-by during commuting disturbances.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: What in the World: China Censors WeChat Rumors, Including the One About Robots Taking Over
item.description: Censorship there is well known, but bureaucrats are also focusing on more mundane matters, seeking to prevent rumors, fabricated news and superstitious premonitions from going viral.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Michelle Obama Stresses Girls’ Education in Visit to Liberia
item.media:description: Princess Lalla Salma of Morocco, right, greeted Michelle Obama at the Marrakesh airport early Tuesday. Mrs. Obama and her daughters are vistiting Africa to promote girls’ education.
item.description: The first lady, whose trip includes stops in Morocco and Spain, urged Liberian teenagers to keep fighting to stay in school.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Brexit Takes Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party to the Brink
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn in London on Monday.
item.media:credit: Dominic Lipinski/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: A referendum intended to heal a rift among Britain’s Conservatives has produced a catastrophic split in the Labour Party.
item.dc:creator: PAUL ANDERSON

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: At Home in London, Not Britain
item.description: After the vote for Brexit, could my family make a life anywhere else in this country?
item.dc:creator: SARFRAZ MANZOOR

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bernie Sanders: Democrats Need to Wake Up
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.description: The rejection of globalization that powered the Brexit movement could happen in the United States. And it may help Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: BERNIE SANDERS

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
